events.title: Button Book Club
events.description: Do you love to read but hate deadlines? Or are you just too busy to attend traditional book club meetings? If so, our Button Book Club is perfect for you! Each month there will be a new book to read and a brand new pin to collect! How It Works Pick Your Book! Each month will feature a new Easy/Picture, Beginning Reader, Middle Grade, and Teen book. Simply pick which level you want to read and check out the book! Share Your Thoughts! Come back anytime during the month and write/draw your favorite part of the book. Get Your Pin! Each book will have it's own special, collectible pin. Participate every month to collect them all! Plus, get a free lanyard with your first pin to show them off!December Books: Easy/Picture: Just One Flake by Travis Jonker Beginning Readers: The Abominable Snowman Doesn't Roast Marshmallows by Debbie Dadey Middle Grade: Grady Jones and the Great Detective Game by Kerry Douglas DyeTeen: Beinoni by Mari Lowe

events.title: Manga of the Month Club
events.description: Do you love manga, but hate in-person book discussions? Try our Manga of the Month Club!Pick up the first volume of the month's chosen series along with a review sheet. Return a completed review sheet to the Westwood Branch at any time and receive a small prize.This activity is recommended for ages 13-18 since the series are typically rated T for Teen.

events.title: Winter Scavenger Hunt
events.description: This is a fun variation on the Adult Winter Checkout Challenge so that kids can get involved, too! Get a bookmark with prompts from the circulation desk then find books that match! Bring the completed bookmark to the front desk for a prize.

events.title: Dial-a-Story for Adults
events.description: Call 612-543-8851 and listen to a recording of staff reading a short story on-demand. The story will change weekly. See the list of previous stories on the Dial-a-Story for Adults book list. Hosted by Outreach Services. Sponsor: Friends of the Hennepin County Library.

events.title: StoryWalk® with Dougherty Station and San Ramon Libraries
events.description: Get some exercise and read the latest story installed at the StoryWalk in Central Park. The winter themed story is called Except Antarctica, written and illustrated by Todd Sturgell. Follow turtle and learn about animals found on every continent except Antarctica!The San Ramon StoryWalk® is a permanent feature in San Ramon’s Central Park. The 20-station project features a new book four times a year. The San Ramon StoryWalk® project is a partnership with the Rotary Club of San Ramon, the City of San Ramon, the San Ramon Library Foundation, and the Library. The Central Park StoryWalk® begins near the Alcosta parking lot to the right of the playground, ending at the Community Center’s rear fountain. The StoryWalk Project was created by Anne Ferguson of Montpelier, VT and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library. StoryWalk is a registered service mark owned by Ms. Ferguson.

location.name: San Ramon Community Center at Central Park

events.title: Matatiki Sewing Club – Create Together!
events.library: Christchurch City Libraries NgÄ Kete WÄnanga o Åtautahi
events.description: Got a sewing project in mind or just want to try something new? Come hang out at the Matatiki Sewing Club! It’s all about creative people getting together and making cool things. Whether you’re a sewing veteran or you’ve never touched a sewing machine, there’s a place for you here. We’ve got sewing machines and all the basics ready for you! Just bring your ideas and some fabric and see what happens. Work on your own thing, swap tips, do your mending or just enjoy the company of other makers. The Sewing Club happens during regular Open Hours, so the space is still available for other creative projects. Free. No bookings required.

events.title: Contemporary Literature Book Club
events.description: The Contemporary Literature Book Club is a friendly and informal group. New participants are always welcome! The group reads current literary fiction, including many Pulitzer Prize winners. Titles are selected based on group suggestions and availability through the library. All meetings are held on the first Thursday of the month at 10 a.m. Contemporary Literature Book Club Reading List

events.title: Read & Write Book Club - for adults learning English
events.description: Want to improve your English reading, writing, and conversation skills? This is the book club for you! We will be reading All I Really Need to Know I Learned in Kindergarten by Robert Fulghum. Copies of the book will be provided. This book club is recommended for adults learning English who are at an intermediate level. Library staff may take photos, videos, or audio recordings at our events. Please tell us if you do not wish to be photographed, video-recorded, or audio-recorded. We will always respect your requests! An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter or closed captioning can be provided for this program if requested at least seven (7) days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - Al Capone Does My Shirts
events.description: Our intermediate ESL Book Club will read Al Capone Does My Shirts by Gennifer Choldenko. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Roberta Linsky. Meeting dates: January 8, 15, 22, 29; February 5, 12Meeting time: Thursdays from 10:00am - 11:00am Where: Tables by the wall posters Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. Book description:Al Capone Does My Shirts is a Newbery Honor-winning historical fiction novel about a boy named Moose who moves with his family to Alcatraz Island in 1935, where his father works as a guard. Living among notorious criminals like Al Capone, Moose navigates family challenges, including his sister's autism, and gets entangled in schemes with the warden's daughter, Piper, leading to humorous and poignant situations.

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - The Great Gatsby
events.description: Intermediate ESL Book Club will read The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then you will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Fernando Lopez. Meeting dates: January 22, 29; February 5, 12, 19Meeting time: Thursdays, 10:30am - 12:00nRegistration is open now! Book club is limited to 7 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting.The Great Gatsby is a Great American Novel of the 20th century. Set in the Jazz Age on Long Island, near New York City, The Great Gatsby depicts the tragic story of Jay Gatsby, a self-made millionaire, and his pursuit of Daisy Buchanan, a wealthy young woman who is his former lover. His doomed love story for the ultimately unattainable Daisy is considered an American dream that is never fulfilled.

events.title: Korean Book Discussion: 밤새들의 도시
events.description: 알바니팍 도서관 한국어 북클럽에 초대합니다. 이번 달에는 김주혜의 <밤새들의 도시>를 읽고 토론합니다. 『작은 땅의 야수들』로 2024년 톨스토이문학상을 수상한 김주혜의 신작 『밤새들의 도시』는 상트페테르부르크, 모스크바, 파리 세 도시를 무대로 완벽한 비상을 꿈꾸는 한 무용수의 치열한 생을 그리고 있습니다. 가난과 결핍을 딛고 세계 최고의 프리마 발레리나가 되지만 그에 따르는 대가 또한 껴안아야 하는 예술가의 빛과 그림자를 동시에 비추며 삶에서 가장 소중한 것을 지키기 위해 우리는 무엇을 기꺼이 희생할 수 있는지를 되묻는 강렬한 이야기입니다. (교보문고 제공)모임은 직접 Little Village Branch에 오시거나 On-Line을 통해 참여하실 수 있습니다. 직접 참여하실 분은 Little Village Branch (2311 S. Kedzie Avenue)로 오세요. 온라인으로 참여하실 분은, 오른쪽 Registration 버튼을 누르고 이메일을 적으세요. 북클럽 24시간 전에 Microsoft Temas 미팅 link를 받게 됩니다. 이 프로그램에 등록하실 때 자동으로 Library Use Guidelines 에 동의하시는 것으로 간주합니다. How to AttendThis event is available in person and online. Attend in person at the Little Village Branch2311 S. Kedzie Avenue. Chicago, Illinois, 60623 Attend online via Microsoft TeamsOnly one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Microsoft Teams meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.description: Explore ambition, power, and persuasion in Shakespeare’s Richard III during this four-week book club. Designed as a casual discussion series, this program welcomes readers of all experience levels—including those new to Shakespeare. Come ready to read, ask questions, and share ideas.Here's our discussion schedule: Thursday, February 5 at 2pm: Act IThursday, February 12 at 2pm: Act IIThursday, February 19 at 2pm: Act IIIThursday, February 26 at 2pm: Acts IV & V

events.title: Choo Choo Club
events.description: Choo Choo Club is a weekly Early Literacy Program that travels through the alphabet one letter at a time. You and your child will play, learn and have fun discovering the early literacy skills that will help them become ready to read! This program is limited to 15 children ages 3-5 and their parents. Registration is required for each event and begins one week in advance. Only the child needs to register. For more information, please call the library at 832-559-4235.

events.title: Elkhorn Eclectics Book Club
events.description: Join OPL on the first Thursday of the month for a lively discussion of this month's featured book. See what we're reading and place holds on upcoming titles here. Limited copies of the book are available at Bess Johnson Elkhorn Branch. OPL Book Club discussions are led by OPL staff and are open to everyone. All Omaha Public Library locations are wheelchair accessible. Need sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please email Nancy Novotny at NNovotny@omahalibrary.org to request accommodation. Requests must be made at least five business days before the activity or event.

events.title: The Genre Jumpers Book Club
events.description: Read a new genre every month! This month, we delve into Romance and Literary Fiction with Aisha Muharrar's debut novel, Loved One. Following the sudden death of her first love, Gabe, thirty-year-old Julia begins an intercontinental quest to recover his possessions. Her search leads to a confrontation with Elizabeth, the woman who last loved Gabe, over his cherished guitar. This witty, heartbreaking novel explores grief, ambiguous loss, and the truths we uncover about those closest to us. Copies will be available at the Information Desk, and the e-book and e-audiobook versions are on Hoopla and CloudLibrary. Preregister. Loved One

events.title: My Zoom Book Club
events.description: Enjoy great reads, lively discussions, and meet fellow book lovers from anywhere. Grab your book & let's chat—this month's pick is The River Is Waiting by Wally Lamb.

events.title: Thursday Afternoon Book Club
events.description: Meet new people and enjoy lively discussions featuring a variety of entertaining and diverse reads. We'll be discussing The Widow's Guide to Dead Bastards by Jessica Waite.Everyone is welcome whether or not you've read this month's book. A limited number of books will be available at the main floor Information Desk one month before the program.Drop-in, no registration required.

events.title: Story Explorers
events.description: Children ages 5-8 can join us on the first Monday of each month for our Time Travel Club. We will travel through time exploring different cultures, and events from the past. This month we will travel back in time to learn about the history of the Super Bowl. We will explore books and stories in creative ways through interactive activities including math, science, games, and more! Each month, we will explore a different topic. This program is for children ages 5-8 years old. Want to be notified about future events? Subscribe to our newsletter here.

events.title: Tutoring Club
events.description: Boost reading and math skills with our KU tutor. Register for an in-person session here. Tutoring in Reading: Pre-K–6th gradeTutoring in Math: K–9th grade This session will meet in the Children's Study Nooks. Check in at the Children's desk upon arrival. Please do not sign up for more than one session a day or two sessions a week. Sessions may be booked up to 2 weeks in advance.

events.title: Cookie Club
events.description: Read and relax at our kids-only book club. This book club is for kids who wish to spend an hour reading books they want to read and eating cookies. Option to share about what you read with others. Cookies provided. Related games available.This program is part of Chicago Public Library's Jump into Reading initiative. For readers 6 and up. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Teen Anime Club
events.description: Each month, participants will watch a new anime, try out different Japanese snack foods, and discuss what anime and manga titles they've been enjoying lately with fellow fans. The majority of the anime we will watch is rated TV-14. This program will be provided by a SouthPark Regional staff member, and is recommended for teens 12-18.

events.title: Kid Book Club
events.description: Calling all first, second and third graders! If you love reading, join us for a fun book exploration. Each session, we’ll dive into a new book with a staff-led talk and activity inspired by the story. Space is limited so registration for each discussion is required. Copies of the books are available for participants while supplies last. Staff will contact participants to distribute books. January: Cat on the Run in Cat of Death! by Aaron BlabeyFebruary: Ricky Ricotta's Mighty Robot by Dav PilkeyMarch: The Fabled Stables: Willa the Wisp by Jonathan AuxierApril: Dory Fantasmagory: Dory Dory Black Sheep by Abby Hanlon For inquiries about accessibility and accommodations, please contact us at ask@jocolibrary.org or 913-826-4600 at least two weeks before the event.

events.title: Popcorn Reading
events.description: Practice your reading skills at our read aloud group. This program is meant for children who need to practice reading aloud. Snacks are provided. For kids 6 and up.How to AttendRegister by the start of the event. Chicago Public Library cannot collect personal information online from kids 0 to 13. A parent or guardian’s email address must be used to register. As a reminder, school email addresses may block external emails such as those from CPL. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Bookin' and Cookin': Two Old Women by Velma Wallis
events.description: Join us for a discussion of Two Old Women. Bring food related to the book to share.---Based on an Athabascan Indian legend passed along for many generations from mothers to daughters of the upper Yukon River Valley in Alaska, this is the suspenseful, shocking, ultimately inspirational tale of two old women abandoned by their tribe during a brutal winter famine.Though these women have been known to complain more than contribute, they now must either survive on their own or die trying. In simple but vivid detail, Wallis depicts a landscape and way of life that are at once merciless and starkly beautiful. In her old women, she has created two heroines of steely determination whose story of betrayal, friendship, community, and forgiveness "speaks straight to the heart with clarity, sweetness, and wisdom" (Ursula K. Le Guin).

events.title: Book Banter: Careless People
events.description: Join us for a fun, engaging discussion of Careless People, by Sarah Wynn-Williams. ---An explosive memoir charting one woman’s career at the heart of one of the most influential companies on the planet, Careless People gives you a front-row seat to Facebook, the decisions that have shaped world events in recent decades, and the people who made them.

This month we will be discussing Ohio by Stephen Markley. Set during one night in northeast Ohio, four old classmates confront their pasts hoping to find closure for lost loves, missed opportunities, and an old disappearance. All book club meetings will be held at Penguin City Brewing Company located at 460 E Federal St. Youngstown, Ohio 44503.

The library will have a selection of titles available from which to choose if you need help in selecting a book.

events.description: Join us for a lively after-hours discussion of My Friends by Fredrik Backman. Our book club meets the first Thursday of each month at 6:30 p.m. New members welcome!

events.title: Reading Buddies at the Renton Highlands Library (Study Zone)
events.description: Volunteers help students practice reading out loud. Two students are paired by reading level with each volunteer. Book selection focuses on readers in grades K-8 and English language learners in grades K-12. Reading Buddies share eBooks on an iPad. Books selection changes every two weeks. Look for volunteers wearing the green Reading Buddies t-shirt. Add your name to the sign-up sheet for a 30-minute spot at your reading level. Study Zone Study Zone programs provide volunteer-led academic support for grades K-12. Programs include Tutors, Math Club, Reading Buddies and Kids & Teens Talk Time. Available online and in libraries. Online Study Zone programs are supervised by library staff. Visit Study Zone for the Terms of Use Agreement and steps KCLS is taking to maintain a safe and positive online space. Reasonable accommodation for people with disabilities is available by request. Email access@kcls.org at least seven days before the event. Automated closed captioning is always available for online events.

events.title: There Will Be Blood Book Club
events.description: Join a fun, informal discussion of great books. This month, we'll discuss The Reformatory by Tananarive Due.

events.title: Making Stories
events.description: Children ages 8 to 12 are invited to join a club that meets on the first Thursday of each month from 3:30-5 pm to write, illustrate, make, and tell your own stories. This is a workshop, where kids can work alone, in pairs, or in small groups to write and illustrate stories. Follow a prompt, do a fun writing or drawing exercise, or free write. Create a book, a zine, a comic, a story, a kamishibai, a play, or whatever! We'll set a date for people who want to read aloud their finished stories and celebrate, and we welcome stories to be added into the library collection. Drop in, no registration required. New members always welcome. Please note: In January, we'll meet on the 2nd Thursday. Get accessibility information.

events.title: Kids Culture Club
events.description: Embark on a global adventure by attending Culture Club on the first Thursday of every month! In each session, young explorers will learn more about an important culture through an engaging activity, such as a craft, game, and/or books and audiovisual media. From making traditional art to viewing a new film, each gathering is a fun-filled journey that fosters curiosity and appreciation for the world’s rich diversity. Perfect for ages 6-11, Culture Club invites kids to connect, create, and celebrate together—one culture at a time! No registration required and all materials will be provided.This month, we're exploring Greek history, culture, and heritage by making scratch art in the shape of Greek vases!

events.title: Reading Era Book Club
events.description: Reading Era Book Club is hosted by the Dayton Metro Library at 201 Tavern. Join us on the first Thursday of every month to discuss the featured book.February's book will be Never Never by Colleen Hoover.201 Tavern is located at 201 Brandt St. Dayton Ohio, 45404, on the corner of Stanview Ave and Brandt St.

events.title: Swashbuckling Heroines and High Seas Adventures with Novelist Vanessa Riley
events.description: Join us for an unforgettable experience as we chat online with Vanessa Riley about her newest book, Fire Sword and Sea, based on the folk story of the female pirate Jacquotte Delahaye. No need to register here but please do register on our partner site. The Caribbean Sea, 1675. Jacquotte Delahaye is the mixed-race daughter of a wealthy tavern owner on the island of Tortuga. Instead of marriage, Jacquotte dreams of joining the seafarers and smugglers whose tall-masted ships cluster in the turquoise waters around Tortuga. In Haiti she becomes Jacques, a dockworker, earning the respect of those around her while hiding her gender. Jacquotte discovers that secret identities are fairly common in the chaotic world of seafaring, which is full of outsiders and misfits. As Jacques, Jacquotte falls in love with Lizzôa d'Erville, a beautiful courtesan who deals in secrets and sex. While others see their work clothes as a disguise, Lizzôa’s true self is as a woman. For the next twenty years, Jacquotte raids the Caribbean, making enemies and amassing a fortune in stolen gold. When her fellow pirates decide to increase their profits by entering the slave trade, Jacquotte turns away from piracy and the pursuit of riches. Risking her life in one deadly skirmish after another, she instead begins to plot a war of liberation. Don’t miss out on this exciting discussion! Register now to embark on a seafaring journey of self discovery and reclamation of personal power. About the Author: Vanessa Riley is an award-winning author and proud recipient of the 2024 Georgia Mystery/Detective Fiction Author of the Year. She writes Sagas and Book Club Fiction that brings to life the hidden narratives of Black women and women of color in novels like Island Queen and Queen of Exiles. Her stories celebrate strong sisterhoods, diverse communities, and resilience across historical fiction, romance, and mystery genres.Her work has been featured in the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, Washington Post, Entertainment Weekly, NPR, Publishers Weekly, and The New York Times.

book.title: Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda

events.title: Virtual Author Talk: Vanessa Riley
events.description: Vanessa Riley delves into Fire Sword and Sea, her newest novel inspired by the legendary pirate Jacquotte Delahaye. Set in the Caribbean of 1675, the story follows Jacquotte as she rejects the life expected of her and disguises herself as “Jacques,” a dockworker who earns respect while concealing her identity. Amid the chaotic world of smugglers and seafarers, she forms deep connections, including a powerful bond with Lizzôa d’Erville, a courtesan who lives her own truth in a world of secrets. Over the next two decades, Jacquotte becomes a feared and successful pirate, amassing wealth and enemies across the Caribbean. But when her crew turns to the slave trade, she refuses to participate and instead risks everything to fight for liberation, transforming her life of piracy into a mission for justice.This program is part of Santa Clara County Library District's celebration of Silicon Valley Reads and African American History Month. --- The free, virtual series is open to the public and takes place two to three times a month. All author talks will include the opportunity to ask the author questions. Click here for a complete list of upcoming events in this series. A link for this event will be sent approximately 24 hours before the event. Participants who register within 24 hours of the event will receive a single email containing the link to the program. This program will be recorded and posted here after the event and will only be available for viewing for a limited time. --- The Santa Clara County Library District is proud to present a virtual monthly author talk series featuring bestselling, award-winning, and highly acclaimed authors from around the world. The featured writers and thought leaders will cover a wide range of fiction and nonfiction genres.---For accessibility accommodations (ex. ASL), please fill out the online form at sccld.org/accessibility 7+days prior to the event. If you need assistance with the form, speak with a staff member at your local library, call (408) 540-3945, or email us at ask@lib.sccgov.org.

events.title: Adult Contemporary Book Discussion: Hum
events.description: Join the Lincoln Park Branch for a discussion of Hum by Helen Phillips. "In a city addled by climate change and populated by intelligent robots called 'hums,' May loses her job to artificial intelligence. In a desperate bid to resolve her family's debt and secure their future for another few months, she becomes a guinea pig in an experiment that alters her face so it cannot be recognized by surveillance. Seeking some reprieve from her recent hardships and from her family's addiction to their devices, she splurges on passes that allow them three nights' respite inside the Botanical Garden. But her insistence that her son, daughter, and husband leave their devices at home proves far more fraught than she anticipated, and the lush beauty of the Botanical Garden is not the balm she hoped it would be"--Copies of the title are available at the circulation desk. Registration is suggested. How to Attend This event takes place in person. Masks are strongly encouraged in all CPL locations. Questions about visiting the library? Check out our Using the Library FAQs. Accessibility Need sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Silent Book Club
events.description: Looking for some dedicated time to read, but don't want to be told WHAT to read? Try out this Silent Book Club! You bring what you're reading, whether it's for another book club or the door stopper you've been working through for months, and you read for an hour. There will be snacks and drinks. We will meet in the Reading Garden. In case of rain, we will meet instead in the Twain meeting room. Registration not required but if you sign up, you'll get a reminder prior to the event!

events.title: Inclusive Book Club with AAC (Online Event)
events.description: Hello Book Club Families, Book of the Week: Nate the Great and the Mushy Valentine by Marjorie Weinman SharmatNate the Great investigates two cases that may be connected, involving a missing valentine and a valentine that came from nowhere. About Our Book Club: Each week, an AAC user hosts our sessions, and a librarian reads our story. After each reading, we enjoy an activity or game connected to the book, celebrating representation, creativity, and the many wonderful ways people communicate. We celebrate all forms of communication—AAC, speech, gestures, and expressions—and follow a Floortime-inspired approach that centers on meeting readers where they are and building joyful shared experiences. When applicable, a visual schedule will be emailed 24 hours before each session to help our readers follow along. Special thanks to Marjorie Weinman Sharmat and Penguin Random House for allowing us to read Nate the Great and the Mushy Valentine in our virtual book club.

Follow turtle and learn about animals found on every continent except Antarctica!The San Ramon StoryWalk® is a permanent feature in San Ramon’s Central Park. The 20-station project features a new book four times a year. The San Ramon StoryWalk® project is a partnership with the Rotary Club of San Ramon, the City of San Ramon, the San Ramon Library Foundation, and the Library. The Central Park StoryWalk® begins near the Alcosta parking lot to the right of the playground, ending at the Community Center’s rear fountain. The StoryWalk Project was created by Anne Ferguson of Montpelier, VT and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library. StoryWalk is a registered service mark owned by Ms. Ferguson.

events.description: This themed, literacy-based drop in program is chock full of activities to help prepare your child for school and beyond. We'll work on motor skills, literacy and counting all while playing in an enriching environment that allows for socialization and for each child to choose their own activity (matching their energy level). Crafts and toddler-friendly snacks will be provided, along with a weekly take-home goody bag to continue learning at home. Manage your event registration through "My Events" when signed in to a library account. DISCOVER MORE Running of out books to read? Ask a librarian for even more personalized recommendations!Visit the Kids Page to discover additional recommendations and resources.

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - Sarah, Plain and Tall
events.description: Our intermediate ESL Book Club will read Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Elaine Hilbelink. Meeting dates: January 9, 16, 23, 30; February 6, 13Meeting time: Fridays 10am - 11am Where: Literacy Table Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. Sarah, Plain and Tall description:Set in the late nineteenth century and told from young Anna's point of view, Sarah, Plain and Tall tells the story of how Sarah Elisabeth Wheaton comes from Maine to the prairie to answer Papa's advertisement for a wife and mother. Before Sarah arrives, Anna and her younger brother Caleb wait and wonder. Will Sarah be nice? Will she sing? Will she stay? This book beautifully covers themes of loss and love, loneliness and belonging, and the change and challenge of forming a new family.

events.title: Trilingual Book Club
events.description: Adults and teens are invited to join us every month for a warm, engaging discussion hosted in English, Farsi, and French. In January, we'll discuss The Little Prince, and in February we'll dive into Peter Pan. Participants will reflect on the messages of each classic book and share their personal insights in a supportive, open environment. Enjoy meaningful dialogue and deeper connection with literature and each other. Hosted by Lantern Book Club.Une série de discussions chaleureuses et inspirantes autour du Petit Prince, explorant les thèmes de l’imagination, de l’amitié, de la responsabilité et de la découverte de soi. Les participants pourront partager leurs réflexions dans un espace ouvert et accueillant. Le programme convient autant aux adolescents qu’aux adultes et invite à une lecture plus profonde de ce classique.تو این برنامه با هم می‌ریم سراغ دنیای «شازده کوچولو»؛ یه جای آروم برای حرف زدن، فکر کردن و دیدن زندگی از زاویه‌های تازه. درباره دوستی، مسئولیت، خیال و شناختِ خودمون حرف می‌زنیم و تجربه‌هامون رو با هم درمیون می‌ذاریم. این دورهمی برای نوجوان‌ها و بزرگسال‌هاست؛ فرصتی برای اینکه این داستان محبوب رو یه جور دیگه تجربه کنید.

events.title: Fletcher Hills Library Book Club
events.description: This month we will be discussing "Our Missing Hearts" by Celeste Ng. About the book:From the number one bestselling author of Little Fires Everywhere, a deeply suspenseful and heartrending novel about the unbreakable love between a mother and child in a society consumed by fear Twelve-year-old Bird Gardner lives a quiet existence with his loving but broken father, a former linguist who now shelves books in a university library. Bird knows to not ask too many questions, stand out too much, or stray too far. For a decade, their lives have been governed by laws written to preserve “American culture” in the wake of years of economic instability and violence. To keep the peace and restore prosperity, the authorities are now allowed to relocate children of dissidents, especially those of Asian origin, and libraries have been forced to remove books seen as unpatriotic—including the work of Bird’s mother, Margaret, a Chinese American poet who left the family when he was nine years old. Bird has grown up disavowing his mother and her poems; he doesn’t know her work or what happened to her, and he knows he shouldn’t wonder. But when he receives a mysterious letter containing only a cryptic drawing, he is drawn into a quest to find her. His journey will take him back to the many folktales she poured into his head as a child, through the ranks of an underground network of librarians, into the lives of the children who have been taken, and finally to New York City, where a new act of defiance may be the beginning of much-needed change. Our Missing Hearts is an old story made new, of the ways supposedly civilized communities can pretend to ignore the most searing injustice. It’s a story about the power—and limitations—of art to create change, the lessons and legacies we pass on to our children, and how any of us can survive a broken world with our hearts intact.

events.title: Climate Conversation: The Lost Words
events.description: Please join us for a discussion about the book The Lost Words and more broadly, climate change and parenthood. The Lost Words is "a beautiful illustrated book for readers young and old. All over the country, there are words disappearing from children's lives. These are the words of the natural world--Dandelion, Otter, Bramble and Acorn, all gone. The rich landscape of wild imagination and wild play is rapidly fading from our children's minds. The Lost Words stands against the disappearance of wild childhood. " Our discussion will be led by Ayesha Qazi-Lampert, an environmental science teacher at Chicago Public Schools. events.title: Pineville Rainbow Reads Teen Book Club
events.description: This club meets monthly to discuss titles that feature LGBTQIA+ writers and characters. This program is provided by Pineville Library Staff and recommended for teens ages 14 to 18 and new adults 18-24. Information about this title:When Prince Xian was a boy, a white snake bit his mother and condemned her to a slow, painful death. The only known cure is an elusive spirit pearl--or an antidote created from the rare white snake itself. Desperate and determined, Xian travels to the city of Changle, where an oracle predicted he would find and capture a white snake. Seven years ago, Zhen, a white snake in the West Lake, consumed a coveted spirit pearl, which gave him special powers--including the ability to change into human form. In Changle, Xian encounters an enigmatic but beautiful stable boy named Zhen. The two are immediately drawn to each other, but Zhen soon realizes that he is the white snake Xian is hunting. As their feelings grow deeper, will the truth about Zhen's identity tear them apart?Looking for the book? Check out our catalog and place a hold:Book: The Legend of the White Snake eBook: The Legend of the White Snake How to Join an Online Program This event takes place on Zoom. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting with a confirmation email from staff. New to using Zoom? Check out these resources to help you get started.

events.title: Documentary Club: I Am Not Your Negro Screening and Discussion
events.description: Welcome to Documentary Club! Each month, libraries across the city will feature a thought-provoking documentary focused on the American experience and history. After the film, stick around to discuss your thoughts and ideas with other attendees led by a librarian. This month, King branch is happy to host Raoul Peck's groundbreaking documentary, I Am Not Your Negro, about the work of James Baldwin. I Am Not Your Negro is an examination of racism in America through the lens of James Baldwin’s unfinished book, Remember This House. Combining Baldwin’s manuscript with footage of depictions of African-Americans throughout American history, I Am Not Your Negro uses Baldwins words to illuminate the pervasiveness of American racism and the efforts to curtail it, from the civil rights movement to #BlackLivesMatter. © Velvet Film | 93 minutes | Not Rated Documentary Club is taking place at other branches! Check out hundreds of other screenings at libraries across Chicago. Accessibility English subtitles for the deaf and hard of hearing will be available for this screening.

events.title: Adv. 3D Printing for Youth
events.description: Ready to take your 3D design skills to the next level? Join us at Advanced 3D Printing for Youth! In this club, we’ll dive deeper into 3D modeling techniques, troubleshoot designs, and experiment with more advanced tools. Whether you want to create functional gadgets, detailed miniatures, or creative prints, this is your chance to push your understanding of 3D printing! EPL staff will provide guidance and feedback as you refine your designs! Each participant’s final design will be 3D printed for free and available for pickup at your local EPL branch. If attendees want to create an object larger than 6cm x 6cm x 6cm, parents must complete the certification and bring a USB to the class so that the Makerspace can support with processing the print! events.description: Indulge in your passion for literature and cuisine at a unique book club where we combine the love of reading with the love of food! For February, instead of everyone reading the same book, we're going to read different books based on a specific theme chosen for the month. Come ready to talk about the book you have read and get some new ideas for your own reading. We are still going to be making and eating a delicious snack inspired by the monthly theme. Don't miss out on this opportunity to bond with fellow book-lovers over a shared love of literature and food.February's theme is, books that have been adapted to the big, or small, screen.To accompany our book talks we will be "adapting" lemons to delicious lemon curd and then to a lemon mousse – simple, delicious and ready in 30 mins. Best adaptation ever!Here's a selection of books and movies to inspire you. All these titles are available at the Library. Tolkien – published Vol. 1-2, 1954 – Vol. 3, 1955 – Films released 2001, 2002, 2003 (director Peter Jackson) Dune by Frank Herbert – published 1965 – Films released 1984 (David Lynch director), TV miniseries 2000 (directed by John Harrison), 2021/2024 parts 1 and 2 (Denis Villeneuve director) The Remains of the Day by Kazuo Ishiguro – published 1989 – Film release - 1993 Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen – published 1813 – Multiple TV and film adaptations 1940 (film), 1995 (TV mini-series), 2005 (film) Station Eleven by Hilary St. John Mandel – published 2014 – 10-episode HBO release – 2021 (8 copies at EPL) American Gods by Neil Gaiman – published 2001 – STARZ TV release 2017-2021 (14 copies at EPL) Jaws by Peter Benchley – published 1974 – Movie released 1975 The Godfather by Mario Puzo – published in 1969 – Movie release 1973 Nothing Lasts Forever by Roderick Thorpe – published in 1979 – movie release “Die Hard” - 1988 NOTE: Registration is required and there is a $5 charge for this class. events.title: Nonfiction Book Discussion: Connecting Dots A Blind Life
events.description: The Cupertino Adult Book Discussion Group is open to all adults who enjoying reading and discussing non-fictional literature. In February the book will be Connecting Dots: A Blind Life by Joshua A. Miele with Wendell Jamieson.Blinded as a young boy, Joshua A. Miele's autobiography talks about how he has negotiated life as a blind person in a world created for sighted people. A born problem solver and naturally curious Miele has spent his life not only figuring out how to live a full life, but helping other blind individuals do the same as an advocate for disability and accessibility. He chronicles the evolution of a number of revolutionary accessible technologies and his role in shaping them, including screen readers, tactile maps, and audio description. Along the way, he grappled with drugs and addiction, played bass in a rock band, worked for NASA, became a guerilla activist, and married the love of his life and had two children. The Adult Nonfiction Book Discussion Group meets on the second Sunday of each month at 11 am in Room 201B. All meetings are sponsored by The Friends of the Cupertino LibraryFor accessibility accommodations (ex. ASL), please fill out the online form at sccld.org/accessibility 7+days prior to the event. If you need assistance with the form, speak with a staff member at your local library, call (408) 540-3945, or email us at ask@sccl.org.

events.title: Cookbook Club: Persian Feasts: Recipes & Stories from a Family Table
events.description: Join Jenny and the Dunning Cookbook Club for a discussion of a monthly cookbook pick and recipe review. Check out the book, test out as many recipes as you like, then we'll dish on what worked and what didn't! If you'd like to bring a recipe from the book, we can provide plates and utensils to make it a party. This month we are discussion Persian Feasts. When Leila Heller's mother, Nahid Taghinia-Milani came to the United States in 1979, she brought her recipes with her. Persian Feasts features Iranian delicacies in a dazzling tapestry of textures and aromas, from Shiraz in the south to Tabriz in the north. This exquisite collection of 100 dishes includes hearty stews, saffron-infused rice dishes, succulent kebabs, and delicate rosewater desserts – each one telling a story that is steeped in tradition and has been passed down from generation to generation. Unexpected ingredient combinations create distinctive tastes and aromas to every dish – from a simple Herb Frittata to a comforting Eggplant, Walnut & Pomegranate Stew to a delicately perfumed Cardamom and Rose Water Pudding. events.title: Manga Monday Book Club
events.description: Enjoy reading manga? Join other teens to discuss stories and characters in our new Manga Monday Club! We will introduce Volume 1 of a series to get you started on your next reading adventure. We encourage teens to read at least Volume 1, whether that is a physical copy from your own manga collection, from our library, or borrowed from a friend. Digital reading also counts; we will be happy to have you participate in our discussion if you have read an e-copy. Physical copies of Volume 1 will be available for in person pick-up at the Enon Branch on a first come, first served basis. Check out Libby and Hoopla for available digital copies. Scheduled for the second Monday of the month. For teens. This month's selection: Fall in Love You False Angels by Coco Uzuki Summary: All sugar, no spice, and everything nice...that's the impression the beautiful first-year high schooler and class president Otogi gives to those around her. One look from the school's "heartthrob angel" is all it takes to sweep countless admirers off their feet. But the real Otogi Katsura is no angel: She's calculating, ruthless, and sharp-tongued. When Otogi slips up and exposes her inner baddie in front of the class's other paragon, Toki, he counters by revealing an unexpected side of his own and declaring her his "partner in crime." With cupid's arrow at her back, can the "heartthrob angel" maintain her perfect act and regain the upper hand, or will she be the one swept off her feet by a fellow false angel?!” Rated 13 +

I don’t feel inspired by America at all,” and the chapters set outside of Africa make this abundantly clear. In this promising novel’s early chapters, Bulawayo’s use of English is disarmingly fresh, her arrangement of words startling." To place a hold on a physical or digital click here.

These podcasts may contain triggering themes and may feature content warnings. events.title: Precious and Adored Book Club! - Precious and Adored by Lizzie Ehrenhalt and Tilly Laskey, Foreword by Lillian Faderman
events.description: The Minnesota History Center is showcasing a number of unique items from the MNHS collections in an exhibit entitled “The Stories We Keep.” This exhibit features 25 objects from MNHS collections—a rich trove built on the generosity and foresight of thousands of people who have entrusted MNHS with their belongings and their stories. To celebrate the exhibit, the History Center has partnered with the Saint Paul Public Library to host a book club featuring Precious and Adored by Lizzie Ehrenhalt and Tilly Laskey. Precious and Adored highlights the correspondence between Rose Cleveland, sister of President Grover Cleveland, and Evangeline Simpson, a wealthy widow who would become the second wife of Henry Whipple, Minnesota's Episcopal bishop. The women corresponded across states and continents, discussing their advocacy and humanitarian work - and demonstrating their sexual attraction, romance, and partnership. Participate in the book club to learn more about this portrayal of nineteenth-century LGBTQ history, then visit “The Stories We Keep” to see original letters from the MNHS collections. Participation in this book club includes a copy of the book and two free passes to the Minnesota History Center to see the exhibit. This book club is for adults.

events.description: A book club dedicated to "Journey to the West," the classic Chinese fiction. This club is designed for children who are fans of the story and is conducted entirely in Mandarin Chinese. The event is organized by dedicated teen volunteers from Lynbrook High School.小朋友们，你们听说过《西游记》吗？ 这是中国最有名的神话故事之一，讲述了一段惊险又有趣的旅程。在这个故事里，有聪明勇敢的孙悟空、善良慈悲的唐僧、憨厚搞笑的猪八戒，还有忠诚可靠的沙和尚。他们一路上经历了许多危险和考验，但靠着智慧和团结，成功完成了任务。这次旅程不仅是他们追寻经书的故事，更是一场关于勇气、坚持和成长的冒险！更多有关 美猴王系列丛书. 免费的亲子中文活動. 座位数量有限. 门票将在故事时间开始前 30 分钟在询问处领取。 圖書館中文资源: 大人最新中文书, 中文電子書, 非小說類電子書 (Overdrive) 有歡迎大家一起來借閱電子書. Overdirve平台: 小朋友的中文電子書, 大朋友的中文電子小說, 大朋友的非小說類的電子書籍. Hoopla平台: 中文有聲書籍 美国残疾人法案(ADA)申请提供协助 5/25/2026

events.title: Lynnwood Library Book Group - "Mrs. Dalloway" by Virginia Woolf
events.description: Join us to celebrate the love of reading with others in our community! This month's selection is Mrs. Dalloway by Virginia Woolf. Heralded as Virginia Woolf's greatest novel, this is a vivid portrait of a single day in a woman's life. When we meet her, Mrs. Clarissa Dalloway is preoccupied with the last-minute details of party preparation while in her mind she is something much more than a perfect society hostess. As she readies her house, she is flooded with remembrances of faraway times. And, met with the realities of the present, Clarissa reexamines the choices that brought her there, hesitantly looking ahead to the unfamiliar work of growing old. Visit the following link to view all of Lynnwood Library Book Group's 2026 selections: Lynnwood Library Book Club 2026 Titles. Books are selected by members of the group and cover a variety of genres. The Lynnwood Library Book Group meets regularly on the second Monday of each month from 6:30-7:45pm. Contact us with questions Programs & Events FAQs To request a sign language interpreter, complete this online form or contact your local library at least two weeks prior to the library event. Interpreters will be provided based on availability.

events.title: Between the Panels: Tween Graphic Novel Book Club
events.description: Calling all tweens? Do you enjoy reading? Are you looking for people to talk about what you’ve just read? Are you down for some book related activities? If your answer is yes to all of the above, sign up for our tween book club to join us for a lively discussion along with a fun activity. This program is for ages 9-12. Registration is required. We will meet in-person in the Spring Branch Memorial Library Meeting Room. Once registered, you will be contacted when a copy of the book is available for pick up. The book we will be reading: Lion Dancers by Cai Tse. Young Wei dreamed of being a legendary lion dancer just like his dad. With his best friend Hung performing as the tail and Wei controlling the head, he knew they could become the next generation of lion dance champions. But after his dad's sudden passing, Wei abruptly quits lion dancing—and his friendship with Hung.Years later, Wei is stuck...in life, in school, and on the bench at games. That is, until he crashes a junior lion dance practice and feels his long-sleeping passion wake up within him once more. The team is happy to have another member to carry on the tradition, especially as one as preternaturally talented as Wei. There's just one person who doesn't want him there: the self-proclaimed star, Hung.As Wei and Hung fight to be considered the top lion dancer, both will have to learn how to face their mistakes head-on and remember what it really means to be part of a team.

events.title: Eco-Book Club: The Serviceberry: Abundance and Reciprocity in the Natural World
events.description: Join Glen staff and volunteers for an informal, fireside discussion of the book The Serviceberry: Abundance and Reciprocity in the Natural World by Robin Wall Kimmerer at the beautiful historic Grinnell Mill. Additional copies of the book available at the YS community library. Book club co-sponsored with the Yellow Springs Community Library. Register for the book club at glenhelen.org.-- All flourishing is mutual”, author Kimmerer begins The Serviceberry. She then leads readers through a poetic, joyful path to the native berry patch and the idea of a gift economy. Kimmerer tells us “the serviceberry shows us another model, one based on reciprocity, where wealth comes from the quality of your relationships, not from the illusions of self-sufficiency.” A lighthearted read interwoven with themes of hope and generosity, defines gifts, whether a basket of juicy serviceberries or physical items, as a part of a moving, reciprocal economy able to bring joy and worthy of our attention.

events.title: The Page Turners
events.description: The Page Turners is an evening book discussion group for adults that meets at the Castro Valley Library on the second Tuesday of the month at 7 pm. Facilitated by librarian Chris Selig, the discussions focus on compelling, well-reviewed fiction and nonfiction books written for adults.For February we will discuss James by Percival Everett, which is available for check out through the Library collection and Link Plus. Synopsis James, is a retelling of The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, that is harrowing, ferociously funny and told from the enslaved Jim's point of view. When the enslaved Jim overhears that he is about to be sold to a man in New Orleans, separated from his wife and daughter forever, he decides to hide on nearby Jackson Island until he can formulate a plan. Meanwhile, Huck Finn has faked his own death to escape his violent father, recently returned to town. As all readers of American literature know, thus begins the dangerous and transcendent journey by raft down the Mississippi River toward the elusive and too-often-unreliable promise of the Free States and beyond. While many narrative set pieces of The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn remain in place (floods and storms, stumbling across both unexpected death and unexpected treasure in the myriad stopping points along the river's banks, encountering the scam artists posing as the Duke and Dauphin...), Jim's agency, intelligence and compassion are shown in a radically new light.James _________ An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter can be provided for this program if requested at least seven business days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - One Foot in the Grape
events.description: Carla's intermediate ESL Book Club will read One Food in the Grap by Carlene O'Neil. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Carla Passero. Meeting dates: January 13, 20, 27; February 3, 10, 17, 24; March 3, 24, 31. (No class March 10 or March 17).Meeting time: Tuesdays, 7:00pm - 8:00pmWhere: CCC Room next to Member Services DeskRegistration is open now! Book club is limited to 8 participants. Books will be provided at the first meeting for registered participants to keep, If you do not show up at the first meeting and have not made arrangements with the tutor, we will give your spot to the next learner on the wait list. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. About the book:One Foot in the Grape is a cozy mystery about ex-photojournalist Penny Lively, who inherits a California winery, only to get tangled in murder when her neighbor's wine is sabotaged and a staff member ends up dead in a grape crusher, making her niece the prime suspect, forcing Penny to solve the crime before her family is ruined. It's the first in the Cypress Cove Mystery series, blending wine country charm with amateur sleuthing and danger.

events.title: Inquisitive Minds: Nonfiction Book Club
events.description: Join us on the 2nd Wednesday of each month at 3pm for Inquisitive Minds: Nonfiction Book Club! We will meet in the Community Room at SouthPark Regional Library. This month (February) we're discussing: A Wilder Shore: The Romantic Odyssey of Fanny and Robert Louis Stevenson by Camille Peri"He was an ambitious but drifting writer from a prominent Scottish family. She was a tough Nevada silver miner’s wife, with children, when they met. Who could have predicted that Fanny Van de Grift and Robert Louis Stevenson would go on to create one of history’s great literary marriages?From their first encounter in France in 1876, Fanny and Louis’s partnership transcended societal expectations to become a literary union that was progressive, eccentric, and tempestuous, but always animated by a profound mutual respect. Seeking creative freedom, inspiration, and better health for Louis, who battled chronic illness, they embarked on a whirlwind journey around the world, from the bohemian enclaves of Europe to the shores of Samoa, where they lived and joined the native islanders’ fight for independence from imperialist powers. Amid the currents of their stormy yet deeply loving relationship, Fanny wrote colorful accounts of her life, contributed to Louis’s work and kept him alive to pen classic novels such as Treasure Island, Kidnapped, and The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde that would go on to resonate with generations of readers.A portrait of two extraordinary people and a testament to the power of love to foster the human spirit, A Wilder Shore unfolds with all the richness and complexity of a timeless epic, capturing the resilience, courage, and devotion that sparked some of our most celebrated and enduring literary masterpieces." This program will be provided by the SouthPark Regional Library staff. Click here to find the book: https://cmlibrary.bibliocommon...Upcoming Reads:March: The Wager: A Tale of Shipwreck, Mutiny and Murder by David GrannApril: Cue the Sun – The Invention of Reality Show TV by Emily Nussbaum

events.title: Virtual Next Chapter Book Club: Top Story
events.description: You're invited to join the Saint Paul Public Library's Next Chapter Book Club as we read Top Story by Kelly Yang. Next Chapter Book Club offers community-based book clubs for adolescents and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Our members (including some who cannot read) love the way books transport them to different worlds where they meet interesting characters and learn about exciting new things. Taking that journey with a group of friends makes it even more delightful and fun. Join us online (click this link to connect to the virtual book club) Wednesdays 5-6 pm until we reach the end of the book. Estimated end date in March. events.title: Fantasy and Science Fiction Book Club: Piranesi by Susanna Clarke
events.description: Join us on the second Wednesday each month to discuss a fantasy or science fiction book! --- This month's title is Piranesi by Susanna Clarke.From the New York Times bestselling author of Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell, an intoxicating, hypnotic new novel set in a dreamlike alternative reality. Piranesi's house is no ordinary building: its rooms are infinite, its corridors endless, its walls are lined with thousands upon thousands of statues, each one different from all the others. Within the labyrinth of halls an ocean is imprisoned; waves thunder up staircases, rooms are flooded in an instant. But Piranesi is not afraid; he understands the tides as he understands the pattern of the labyrinth itself. He lives to explore the house. There is one other person in the house-a man called The Other, who visits Piranesi twice a week and asks for help with research into A Great and Secret Knowledge. But as Piranesi explores, evidence emerges of another person, and a terrible truth begins to unravel, revealing a world beyond the one Piranesi has always known. For readers of Neil Gaiman's The Ocean at the End of the Lane and fans of Madeline Miller's Circe, Piranesi introduces an astonishing new world, an infinite labyrinth, full of startling images and surreal beauty, haunted by the tides and the clouds

events.title: Read the World: A Middle Grade Book Club
events.description: Read the World is a book discussion group for youth in 6th to 9th grade. Each month we'll read a book set in a different country then enjoy conversations about the book as well as other cultures and experiences. We'll read from multiple categories, including fiction, nonfiction, graphic novels, novels in verse, and more. This month we'll be reading and discussing Amal Unbound by Aisha Saeed and set in Pakistan. Please register then stop by the library for a free copy of the book no earlier than one month before the discussion."Twelve-year-old Amal's dream of becoming a teacher one day is dashed in an instant when she accidentally insults a member of her Pakistani village's ruling family. As punishment for her behavior, she is forced to leave her heartbroken family behind and go work at their estate. Amal is distraught but has faced setbacks before. So she summons her courage and begins navigating the complex rules of life as a servant, with all its attendant jealousies and pecking-order woes. Most troubling, though, is Amal's increasing awareness of the deadly measures the Khan family will go to in order to stay in control. It's clear that their hold over her village will never loosen as long as everyone is too afraid to challenge them--so if Amal is to have any chance of ensuring her loved ones' safety and winning back her freedom, she must find a way to work with the other servants to make it happen." Amal Unbound An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter can be provided for this program if requested at least seven (7) business days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

events.title: Dayton's Bluff Book Club
events.description: Dayton's Bluff Book Club is a great fit for folks who love reading diverse books by local authors and discussing them with a group of dedicated readers. We meet once a month on a Wednesday in the months of October, November, December, February, March, and April at 6 p.m. We have a limited supply of free books for book club participants that will be available for pick up at the Dayton's Bluff Branch Library when selections become finalized. Participants will be notified by email. Books will also be available to borrow at the library. The Dayton’s Bluff Book Club is a collaboration of the Metropolitan State University Library and the Dayton’s Bluff Branch of Saint Paul Public Library whose members live, work or attend classes on the East Side. We prioritize our selection of titles to those written by Minnesota authors, that have a local setting, or that are written by people of color and other diverse authors. Book discussions usually include issues related to social justice, equity, and anti-racism. We encourage book club members to use both the university and public libraries in pursuit of lifelong learning and the joy of reading. Discussions are frequently facilitated by authors, Metropolitan State faculty, or other guests from the community. The House on RondoWelcome - Dayton's Bluff Book Club - LibGuides at Metropolitan State University

events.title: (Virtual) Pearl Avenue Book Club
events.description: The Pearl Avenue Book Club meets virtually, on the 2nd Wednesday of the month, at 5:30 p.m. All are welcome to join in the lively discussions. Currently, the Club is meeting on zoom. If you register, you will be contacted with the link on the day of the program. Wednesday, February 11, 2026, 5:30 p.m. Iona Iverson's Rules for Commuting, by Clare Pooley.Nobody ever talks to strangers on the train. It's a rule. But what would happen if they did? From the New York Times bestselling author of The Authenticity Project, a heartwarming novel about unexpected friendships and the joy of connecting. Every day, Iona, a larger-than-life magazine advice columnist, travels the ten stops from Hampton Court to Waterloo Station by train, accompanied by her dog, Lulu. Every day she sees the same people, whom she knows only by nickname: Impossibly-Pretty-Bookworm and Terribly-Lonely-Teenager. Of course, they never speak. Seasoned commuters never do. Then one morning, the man she calls Smart-But-Sexist-Manspreader chokes on a grape right in front of her. He'd have died were it not for the timely intervention of Sanjay, a nurse, who gives him the Heimlich maneuver. This single event starts a chain reaction, and an eclectic group of people with almost nothing in common except their commute discover that a chance encounter can blossom into much more. It turns out that talking to strangers can teach you about the world around you--and even more about yourself. Wednesday, March 11, 2026, 5:30 p.m. "Downton Shabby," by Hopwood DePree. Wednesday, April 8, 2026, 5:30 p.m. "Speak to Me of Home," by Jeanine Cummins.Wednesday, May 13, 2026, 5:30 p.m. TBDWednesday, June 10, 2026, 5:30 p.m. TBDWednesday, July , 2026, 5:30 p.m. TBDWednesday, August 12, 2026, 5:30 p.m. TBDWednesday, September 9, 2026, 5:30 p.m. TBDWednesday, October 14, 2026, 5:30 p.m. TBDWednesday, November 11, 2026, 5:30 p.m. TBD Wednesday, December 9, 2026, 5:30 p.m. TBDADA Accommodation Requests

The 20-station project features a new book four times a year. The San Ramon StoryWalk® project is a partnership with the Rotary Club of San Ramon, the City of San Ramon, the San Ramon Library Foundation, and the Library. events.title: Getting Cozy Book Club
events.description: If you've never read a cozy mystery before or if you have read thousands, join us each month as we read and discuss the first book in a series. We will meet on the 2nd Thursday of the month at 10 am. What is a cozy mystery? The crime-solver is an amateur sleuth, who eavesdrops, gathers clues, and uses their native intelligence and knowledge of their community to solve the crime. Cozy mysteries are generally considered “gentle” books and most have no graphic violence. The setting is often a small town full of colorful characters.Series frequently have a prominent thematic element introduced by the detective's job, pet, or hobby.These books are plot and character driven with an emphasis on solving puzzles rather than suspense. Our chosen book with serve as our theme for the meeting, we will talk about other book series with a similar theme as well as the recipes, crafts, and more included in many cozies.

Meeting dates: January 8, 15, 22, 29; February 5, 12Meeting time: Thursdays from 10:00am - 11:00am Where: Tables by the wall posters Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. Book description:Al Capone Does My Shirts is a Newbery Honor-winning historical fiction novel about a boy named Moose who moves with his family to Alcatraz Island in 1935, where his father works as a guard. Living among notorious criminals like Al Capone, Moose navigates family challenges, including his sister's autism, and gets entangled in schemes with the warden's daughter, Piper, leading to humorous and poignant situations.

events.description: Do you love to read? Have a favourite book you want to recommend? Join us to meet fellow book lovers and get ideas about what to read next. events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - The Great Gatsby
events.description: Intermediate ESL Book Club will read The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then you will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Fernando Lopez. Meeting dates: January 22, 29; February 5, 12, 19Meeting time: Thursdays, 10:30am - 12:00nRegistration is open now! Book club is limited to 7 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting.The Great Gatsby is a Great American Novel of the 20th century. Set in the Jazz Age on Long Island, near New York City, The Great Gatsby depicts the tragic story of Jay Gatsby, a self-made millionaire, and his pursuit of Daisy Buchanan, a wealthy young woman who is his former lover. His doomed love story for the ultimately unattainable Daisy is considered an American dream that is never fulfilled.

events.description: Looking for a laid-back, adults-only book club with no required reading? Join our Reader’s Choice book club, where you can share whatever you’re currently reading! Can’t make it to the meeting? Check out the Lit Chat Podcast, featuring our library staff and volunteers on Spotify, iHeartRadio, Apple, Amazon or Audible!

events.title: Civic Center Morning Mystery Book Group: 'Razorblade Tears' by S.A. Cosby
events.description: The Civic Center Library's Morning Mystery Book Club will meet on Thursday, February 12th from 11:00am-12:00pm to discuss Razorblade Tears by S.A. Cosby. This mystery book club generally meets on the 2nd Thursday of every month from 11:00-12:00n. All are welcome to join! Request a copy of the book online or ask at the Info Desk of the Civic Center Library (or call 415-473-6057) for assistance in placing a hold. Razorblade Tears (book) or Razorblade Tears (eAudiobook) by S.A. Cosby A Black father. A white father. Two murdered sons. A story of bloody retribution, heartfelt change, and maybe even redemption. Ike Randolph has been out of jail for fifteen years, with not so much as a speeding ticket in all that time. But a Black man with cops at the door knows to be afraid. The last thing he expects to hear is that his son Isiah has been murdered, along with Isiah’s white husband, Derek. Ike had never fully accepted his son but is devastated by his loss. Derek’s father Buddy Lee was almost as ashamed of Derek for being gay as Derek was ashamed of his father's criminal record. Buddy Lee still has contacts in the underworld, though, and he wants to know who killed his boy. Ike and Buddy Lee, two ex-cons with little else in common other than a criminal past and a love for their dead sons, band together in their desperate desire for revenge. In their quest to do better for their sons in death than they did in life, hardened men Ike and Buddy Lee will confront their own prejudices about their sons and each other, as they rain down vengeance upon those who hurt their boys. - adapted from the publisher ADA Accommodation Request | Solicitud de Adaptación ADA

events.title: Fairfax Book Club: On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous by Ocean Vuong
events.description: The Fairfax Library Thursday Morning Book Club will meet in-person every other month to discuss a new book. Everyone is welcome to attend whether or not you have read the selected book for that meeting. This is a drop-in event, and February 12 is our first book club meeting in 2026. We gather in person at the Fairfax Library for this conversation.We will be discussing our selection: On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous by Ocean Vuong On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous is a letter from a son to a mother who cannot read. Written when the speaker, Little Dog, is in his late twenties, the letter unearths a family's history that began before he was born -- a history whose epicenter is rooted in Vietnam -- and serves as a doorway into parts of his life his mother has never known, all of it leading to an unforgettable revelation. At once a witness to the fraught yet undeniable love between a single mother and her son, it is also a brutally honest exploration of race, class, and masculinity. Available Formats: Print Book & Large-Type Print, Audiobook Download, E-Print bookFairfax Book Club is sponsored by the Friends of the Fairfax Library. ADA Accommodation Request | Solicitud de Adaptación ADA

events.title: Virtual Author Talk: Dr. Lindsey Stewart
events.description: Dr. Lindsey Stewart’s The Conjuring of America traces 400 years of Black women’s magic through the lives of enslaved Mammies, Voodoo Queens, Blues Women, Granny Midwives, and textile weavers who preserved their spiritual practices in secrecy across generations. Stewart shows how conjure has shaped everyday American life, influencing everything from traditional medicines that inspired products like Vicks VapoRub to cultural touchstones such as The Little Mermaid and even the origins of blue jeans. Drawing on letters from the enslaved and the lore of Oshun and other African mystics, Stewart reveals how conjure persisted despite being regulated and outlawed from the moment Africans arrived in America. Her book serves as a tribute to the herbs, food, textiles, song, and dance Black women used to nurture resistance, freedom, and hope.This program is part of Santa Clara County Library District's celebration of Silicon Valley Reads. --- The free, virtual series is open to the public and takes place two to three times a month. All author talks will include the opportunity to ask the author questions. Click here for a complete list of upcoming events in this series. A link for this event will be sent approximately 24 hours before the event. Participants who register within 24 hours of the event will receive a single email containing the link to the program. This program will be recorded and posted here after the event and will only be available for viewing for a limited time. --- The Santa Clara County Library District is proud to present a virtual monthly author talk series featuring bestselling, award-winning, and highly acclaimed authors from around the world. The featured writers and thought leaders will cover a wide range of fiction and nonfiction genres.---For accessibility accommodations (ex. ASL), please fill out the online form at sccld.org/accessibility 7+days prior to the event. If you need assistance with the form, speak with a staff member at your local library, call (408) 540-3945, or email us at ask@lib.sccgov.org.

events.title: Book Clubs of EPL: Everyone in My Family Has Killed Someone
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Come join us for lively discussions on all types of fiction and non-fiction. We'll feature different titles and authors each month. Join us to share your impressions, thoughts and interpretations of a book we have all read. "Everyone In My Family Has Killed Someone" by Benjamin Stevenson SYNOPSIS: "Everyone in my family has killed someone. Some of us, the high achievers, have killed more than once. I'm not trying to be dramatic, but it is the truth. Some of us are good, others are bad, and some just unfortunate. I'm Ernest Cunningham. Call me Ern or Ernie. I wish I'd killed whoever decided our family reunion should be at a ski resort, but it's a little more complicated than that. Have I killed someone? Yes. I have. Who was it? Let's get started"

events.title: Out & About Reading Party

This nontraditional book club meets on the second Thursday of each month.This month we are visiting Luli Creative! Check out the location details about access and parking. This program is for readers age 16 and up. 2025-2026 titles: September 11: Understanding Comics by Scott McCloud (1994), 224 pagesOctober 9: Artificial: A Love Story by Amy Kurzweil (2023), 368 pagesNovember 13: The Road by Cormac McCarthy (2024), 160 pagesDecember 11: The House by Paco Roca (2019), 134 pagesJanuary 8: In: A Graphic Novel by Will McPhail (2021), 272 pagesFebruary 12: Special presentations by book club members who are authors: Mimi & Soni Discover Dussehra Legends by Devika Joglekar (2019), Kye in the Valley of Gold by Kyle Hurlbut (2024), Smiling Through the Mask by Daniele Archambault (2022), as well as artist Deborah J. Miller who will be sharing her current project.March 12: Feeding Ghosts by Tessa Hulls (2024), 400 pagesApril 9: Yellow Cab by Benoit Cohen (2022), 168 pagesMay 14: 40 Men and 12 Rifles: Indochina 1954 by Marcelino Truong (2023), 296 pagesTitles can be borrowed from the Palo Alto City Library and through our Link+ system - click on the links above or search in our catalog for more information. Meetings are held in person in the Midtown Room at Mitchell Park Library and facilitated by Danièle Archambault. The GNBC has been meeting since 2015! Danièle Archambault, Ph.D. (Linguistics), is a researcher, author, and educator who is interested in comics as a way to document a society's cultural and linguistic landscape. Originally from Montreal, Quebec, she now lives in Palo Alto, where she is an artist in residence at the Cubberley Artist Studio Program, a program of the City of Palo Alto. In the past few years, she has published several full-color comic books, graphic novels, and electronic books. Ms. Archambault is a regular guest speaker on documenting culture and dialects through comics at various educational and cultural institutions. She teaches Visual Storytelling at the Palo Alto Art Center, and at other educational venues. http://danielebd.com/

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - Sarah, Plain and Tall
events.description: Our intermediate ESL Book Club will read Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Elaine Hilbelink. Meeting dates: January 9, 16, 23, 30; February 6, 13Meeting time: Fridays 10am - 11am Where: Literacy Table Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. Sarah, Plain and Tall description:Set in the late nineteenth century and told from young Anna's point of view, Sarah, Plain and Tall tells the story of how Sarah Elisabeth Wheaton comes from Maine to the prairie to answer Papa's advertisement for a wife and mother. Before Sarah arrives, Anna and her younger brother Caleb wait and wonder. Will Sarah be nice? Will she sing? Will she stay? This book beautifully covers themes of loss and love, loneliness and belonging, and the change and challenge of forming a new family.

events.title: Graphic Novel Book Club: Kindred Dragons
events.description: Join other readers to discuss a different graphic novel each month. Ages 10-14. Registration required. --- This month we're reading Kindred Dragons Book 1 by Sarah Mensinga. "Alice has been unhappy ever since her parents sent her to Prince Edward Island to live with her strict grandmother. Alice is fanciful, prone to telling tall tales, and absolutely obsessed with dragons! Fairies deliver dragon eggs to a select few, known as Kindreds, but no egg has ever arrived for Alice. While wandering the woods alone, she finds and secretly befriends a mysterious old dragon named Brim. Alice is excited to finally have a dragon friend of her own, but when Brim suddenly falls ill, Alice must set out on a desperate quest to save him. As Alice searches for a cure, she discovers that her connection to dragons is unlike that of any Kindred— but will her new power be enough to save her friend? Let your imagination take flight in this heartfelt story of friendship, family, and learning to love who you are!"

events.title: 👨‍💼📝TAC (Teen Advisory Committee) 🧑‍⚖️👨‍💼🧑‍💻📜📝
events.description: Join the Teen Advisory Committee (TAC): Lead, Serve, and Create! Are you a teen in grades 7–12 looking to make a real impact in your community? The West University Branch Library is seeking motivated young leaders to join the Teen Advisory Committee (TAC). As a formal body of teen advocates, the TAC bridges the gap between Harris County youth, community, and library administration through service, advocacy, and leadership. Why Join TAC? Becoming a member is more than just joining a club; it is a professional leadership position that offers significant benefits for your future that may include: Earn Volunteer Hours: Receive official service hours for attending monthly meetings and assisting with library initiativesDevelop Core Skills: Build a competitive resume by gaining experience in project management, public speaking, and strategic planning.Exclusive Perks: Get "first dibs" on new Young Adult (YA) books and Manga arrivals, and receive a formal Letter of Recommendation upon successful completion of your termReal Influence: Manage a "micro-budget" to choose committee snacks or décor and help curate the library’s collection What You’ll Do As a TAC member, you are a civic consultant for the library. Your responsibilities may include: Event Planning: Brainstorming and hosting events like gaming tournaments, craft workshops, or "Comic-Con" task forcesAdvocacy: Suggesting new Manga or YA titles and ensuring teen spaces meet the needs of your peers.Outreach: Creating promotional content for social media and coordinating with local school clubs. How to Apply Ready to lead? Interested students must submit a formal membership application and complete a brief orientation interview with the Staff Liaison, Mike.
